head.title: Flexible High-Efficiency CZTSSe Solar Cells on Diverse Flexible Substrates via an Adhesive-Bonding Transfer Method | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Flexible High-Efficiency CZTSSe Solar Cells on Diverse Flexible Substrates via an Adhesive-Bonding Transfer Method

Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) thin-film solar cells are showing great promise due to using earth-abundant and nontoxic materials and tuning the band gap through the amount of S and Se. Flexible high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cells are one of the outstanding research challenges because they currently require the use of thick glass substrates due to the high-temperature heat treatment process, and for this reason, few flexible CZTSSe solar cells have been reported. Furthermore, most researchers have used thin glass and metal substrates with little flexibility; the power conversion efficiency (PCE or η) values of the solar cells made with them have been slightly lower. To overcome these hurdles, we transferred high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cells formed on a soda-lime glass substrate to flexible substrates via an adhesive-bonding transfer method. Through this method, we were able to achieve the PCE of 5.8–7.1% on completely flexible substrates such as cloth, paper, and poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET). In particular, we were able to produce a CZTSSe solar cell on a PET substrate with a PCE of 7.1%, which is the highest among fully flexible CZTSSe solar cells currently known to us. In addition, we deeply analyzed the PCE degradation of the flexible CZTSSe solar cell fabricated by the transfer method through a panoramic focused ion-beam image and nanoindentation. From the results of our work, we provide an insight into the possibility of making flexible high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cells using our transfer method.

div.p:
Cu
2
ZnSn(S,Se)
4
(CZTSSe) thin-film solar cells are showing great promise due to using earth-abundant and nontoxic materials and tuning the band gap through the amount of S and Se. Flexible high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cells are one of the outstanding research challenges because they currently require the use of thick glass substrates due to the high-temperature heat treatment process, and for this reason, few flexible CZTSSe solar cells have been reported. Furthermore, most researchers have used thin glass and metal substrates with little flexibility; the power conversion efficiency (PCE or η) values of the solar cells made with them have been slightly lower. To overcome these hurdles, we transferred high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cells formed on a soda-lime glass substrate to flexible substrates via an adhesive-bonding transfer method. Through this method, we were able to achieve the PCE of 5.8–7.1% on completely flexible substrates such as cloth, paper, and poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET). In particular, we were able to produce a CZTSSe solar cell on a PET substrate with a PCE of 7.1%, which is the highest among fully flexible CZTSSe solar cells currently known to us. In addition, we deeply analyzed the PCE degradation of the flexible CZTSSe solar cell fabricated by the transfer method through a panoramic focused ion-beam image and nanoindentation. From the results of our work, we provide an insight into the possibility of making flexible high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cells using our transfer method.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Renewable energy such as solar, hydrogen, and biomass energy offers a solution to prevent environmental problems caused by climate change and to sustain economic growth.
(1−3)
Solar energy is a promising candidate because it is possible to produce almost infinite energy from sunlight without harmful environmental issues. To date, many attempts have been made into researching solar cells.
(4−9)
In particular, inorganic-based solar cells made from materials such as Si, CdTe, Cu(InGa)Se
2
, and Cu
2
ZnSn(S,Se)
4
(CZTSSe) are the mainstream due to their stability in strong sunlight or the external environment compared with organic-based ones.
(6−10)

CZTSSe used in inorganic-based thin-film solar cells has been recently attracting attention due to a favorable band gap (1–1.5 eV) and absorption coefficient (∼10
4
cm
–1
) to obtain high power conversion efficiency (PCE).
(9,10)
Furthermore, it has advantages from both environmental and economic points of view because of using eco-friendly and earth-abundant Sn and Zn instead of Cd (a toxic substance) and expensive In and Ga metals.
(11)
Despite the numerous advantages of CZTSSe solar cells, they present several challenges, such as their heaviness and lack of flexibility due to using heavy substrates. In addition to the advantages of existing CZTSSe solar cells, it is important to develop flexible lightweight CZTSSe solar cells with high efficiency. Previous studies on flexible CZTSSe solar cells (FCSs) have been limited by the use of a metal foil having a small amount of flexibility as a substrate, and even though flexible CZTSSe solar cells on a completely flexible substrate such as polyimide have been demonstrated, the reported PCE was insufficient.
(12−18)

Although Zhou et al. reported a flexible CuZnSnS
4
(CZTS) solar cell on a polyimide substrate with a microparticle-by-screen-printing method, the PCE was limited to 0.49%.
(15)
In addition, Peng et al. and Zhang et al. developed flexible CZTS solar cells on a 100 μm thick flexible glass and a 500 μm thick Mo foil substrate with PCEs of 3.08 and 3.82%, respectively.
(16,17)
Recently, Yang et al. reported a CZTSSe solar cell with a high PCE of 7.04%, but this was also limited by the use of a substrate of Mo foil.
(18)
All of the aforementioned flexible CZTS and CZTSSe solar cells were fabricated by directly forming an absorber layer on a substrate with limited flexibility. Although there is a way to make flexible CZTSSe solar cells directly on flexible substrates like previous studies, one of the ways to fabricate flexible high-efficiency solar cells without substrate constraints is to manufacture high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cells and transfer them to flexible substrates such as poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET), paper, and cloth.

Herein, we report the fabrication of high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cells on soda-lime glass (SLG) via a high-temperature annealing process. Compared to CZTS and CuZnSnSe
4
, CZTSSe solar cells are a good way to fabricate high-efficiency solar cells by adjusting the band gap to maximize the PCE.
(9,10,19−22)
We were able to fabricate CZTSSe solar cells on SLG having PCEs up to 9.3% and characterize the solar cells with X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectra, and external quantum efficiency (EQE). Based on the CZTSSe solar cell on SLG, we first removed the rigid glass substrates by mechanical and chemical etching through lapping and hydrofluoric acid (HF) solution. Thanks to the Mo layer acting as the etching stop layer in this work, we were able to transfer the very thin CZTSSe solar cells (∼5 μm) onto various flexible substrates such as PET, paper, and clothing. In particular, the PCE of the fully flexible CZTSSe solar cell fabricated with PET is 7.1%, which is the highest reported so far for flexible solar cells using polymer substrates (
Table S1
in the Supporting Information). Furthermore, we were able to obtain the first flexible CZTSSe solar cells on paper and cloth with PCEs of 6.2 and 5.8%, respectively.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We investigated the properties of the OCSs through cross-sectional transmission electron microscopy (TEM), XRD, Raman spectra, EQE, and a solar simulator before the adhesive-bonding transfer process, as can be seen in
Figure
1
.
Figure
1
a shows a schematic of the fabrication process of the OCSs (see the
Section 4
for details), and the details of the profile for the annealing process are shown in
Figure S1
. From the TEM results in
Figure
1
b, the thickness of the CZTSSe absorber was ∼2 μm with a 500 nm thick MoS
2
/MoSe
2
layer. In general, voids and a thick MoS
2
/MoSe
2
layer are known to be harmful to the CZTSSe/Mo interface and lead to performance degradation. To minimize this effect, we deposited an optimized bilayer structure of the Mo layer that is known to be relatively less harmful to the device performance.
(21,23)
The total thickness of the device including the 1 μm thick Al electrodes (not seen in the TEM image) was up to ∼5 μm. Moreover, we investigated the Cu, Zn, Sn, S, Se, Mo, and Cd components through TEM energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (TEM-EDX) mapping and confirmed that each was detected uniformly in each layer (
Figure S2
). The high-efficiency CZTSSe absorber usually has Cu-poor and Zn-rich elemental compositions.
(9,10)
By using EDX, we found that the compositional ratio of the CZTSSe absorption layer was Cu/(Zn + Sn) = 0.56, Zn/Sn = 1.51, and (Se + S)/metal = 0.95 (
Table S2
).
Figure
1
c shows the XRD results of the absorption layer of the representative sample and the reference data for CZTS and CZTSe. Our CZTSSe absorption layer showed primary peaks (other than the Mo electrode peaks) at 27, 46, 54, and 73°. When comparing CZTS (JCPDS No. 26-0575) and CZTSe (JCPDS No. 52-0868), the peaks of our CZTSSe absorption layers are closer to the CZTSe profile than the CZTS profile. Therefore, the ratio of Se atoms seems to be higher than that of S atoms. The trend shown in the XRD analysis was the same as that in the Raman analysis. As shown in
Figure
1
d, the CZTSe peak (200 cm
–1
) was relatively high compared to the CZTS peak (325 cm
–1
). The secondary phases, which have a detrimental effect on CZTSSe solar cells, were not detected.
(24)
Based on this verification, we manufactured three OCSs according to the flexible substrates used in this work: OCS_PET, OCS_Paper, and OCS_Cloth for PET, paper, and cloth substrates, respectively. Note that there were no differences in the processing conditions for the three substrates. To analyze the quantum efficiency and band gap, we measured their EQEs: OCS_PET showed up to 90% at 600 nm, followed by OCS_Cloth and OCS_Paper, as can be seen in
Figure
1
e. We calculated [
h
ν × ln(1 – EQE)]
2
vs
h
ν to estimate the bandgaps and band gap energies of the OCS_PET, OCS_Paper, and OCS_Cloth, which were 1.09, 1.11, and 1.11 eV, respectively (
Figure S3
). In addition, we recorded the fundamental characteristics of all of the OCSs used for fabricating the flexible CZTSSe solar cells (FCSs): open-circuit voltage (
V
oc
), short-circuit current density (
J
sc
), fill factor (FF), PCE, shunt resistance (
R
sh
), and series resistance (
R
s
) (
Table S3
). The cell dimension of the CZTSSe solar cells was 0.19 cm
2
. The OCSs had PCEs of 1.9–8.3%,
V
oc
of 223–451.1 mV,
J
sc
of 27.3–34.6 mA/cm
2
, and FFs of 31–59.2%. Although the PCEs of the fabricated solar cell seemed to vary greatly from a minimum of 1.9% to a maximum of 8.3%, it was 6.2–8.3%, which is relatively uniform, when not including OCS_Paper 6 (1.9%).
J
–
V
curves and values for the representative OCSs can be seen in
Figure
1
f and are reported in
Table
1
.

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Fabrication process and (b) a cross-sectional TEM image of the original CZTSSe solar cells (OCSs). (c) XRD results and (d) Raman spectrum of the CZTSSe thin film with CZTS and CZTSe reference data. (e) EQEs and extracted band gap energies and (f)
J
–
V
characteristics of the OCSs.

div.div: Table 1. Device Characteristics of the Original CZTSSe Solar Cells before Transfer onto Various Flexible Substrates

We manufactured the high-efficiency FCSs on diverse flexible substrates based on the OCSs through a transfer method.
Figure
2
a shows a schematic diagram of the adhesive-bonding transfer process of the CZTSSe solar cells onto diverse flexible substrates: PET, paper, and cloth (see the
Section 4
for more information). The practical fabrication process is indicated in
Figure S4
through digital camera images. As shown in
Figure S5a
, the thermal release tape (TRT) film had nanosized voids among the polymers that act as the adhesive, thus the HF solution could penetrate the surface of the CZTSSe cell and remove the Al electrodes during chemical etching if we only used TRT. To prevent this, 100 nm thick poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) was first coated on the surface of CZTSSe cells to protect it and a TRT supporting layer was added afterward. Optical microscopy images of the TRT residue were taken to identify whether any residue remained after the TRT supporting layer had been removed (
Figure S5b,c
). Very small dots can be observed in
Figure S5c
, but they remained on the surface of the completed CZTSSe solar cell and therefore did not affect the electrical properties of the device. Because the effect of these dots on transmittance is also low, we surmise that there was little damage to the surface area by the TRT. Contrary to the top surface of the CZTSSe cells, there were Mo layers on the bottom that could act as an etching stop layer to prevent penetration by the HF solution. Typically, although Mo films can be wet-etched by a wet etchant based on HF, practical wet etching is performed with a mixture of HF and HNO
3
or HF and H
2
O
2
. Thus, the solution containing only HF was unable to penetrate the Mo layers, which thus served as a barrier to prevent the HF solution from penetrating into the CZTSSe absorption layer.
(25)
Thanks to the Mo layers, we were able to obtain intact TRT/PMMA/CZTSSe solar cell/Mo layer structures after we removed the rigid glass substrate. Adhesive conductive epoxy was coated by screen-printing onto the surface of the Mo layer on the bottom surface of the aforementioned structure, which was then transferred to the target flexible substrate through adhesive bonding; this is a stable transfer method regardless of the roughness of the surface of the sample and the target substrate.
(26)
By using the polymer-based adhesive bonding, we were able to transfer the CZTSSe solar cells stably onto the diverse flexible substrates: PET, paper, and even cloth. Finally, heat was applied to the TRT to detach it and the PMMA was removed to complete the final FCSs, as can be seen in
Figure
2
b. The OCS transferred to the PET film was instantaneously frozen with liquid nitrogen and then cut to confirm the cross section of the resulting FCS.
Figure
2
c presents a cross-sectional scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of the FCS, and the thickness of the adhesive layer composed of a mixture of silver flake and epoxy is ∼10 μm. A schematic of the FCS structure fabricated on a PET substrate is shown in
Figure S6
.

div.p: Figure 2. (a) Fabrication process of the flexible CZTSSe solar cells (FCSs) divided into the high-efficiency solar cell fabrication step (i), the rigid substrate removal steps (ii)–(iv), and the transfer steps (v) and (vi). (b) A photo and (c) a cross-sectional SEM image of the FCS_PET.

div.div:
We were able to fabricate the FCSs on fully flexible substrates: PET (FCS_PET), paper (FCS_Paper), and cloth (FCS_Cloth), as can be seen in
Figure
3
a.
Figure
3
b shows the PCEs of the CZTSSe solar cells before transfer and the FCSs after transfer. On the basis of the PCE results for all of the FCSs, we were able to confirm that the cause of the decrease in PCEs between the OCSs and FCSs was independent of the substrates. After the transfer, efficiency deterioration occurred irregularly in PET, paper, and cloth substrates. We recorded the overall properties of the FCSs except for FCS_Paper 6 due to being unable to measure its PCE, as reported in
Table S4
. We believe that the FCS_Paper 6 solar cell was a failure because the PCE of OCS_Paper 6 itself was unusual. We report the overall properties of the selected FCSs in
Table
2
. The
J
sc
and FF values of the FCSs were 26.7–28.2 mA/cm
2
and 49.8–53.9%, respectively, which were slightly lower than those of the OCSs (27.6–34.6 mA/cm
2
and 53.8–57.2%, respectively), while their
V
oc
values were similar. The PCEs of OCS_PET, OCS_Paper, and OCS_Cloth were 8.3, 7.6, and 6.4%, respectively, while those of FCS_PET, FCS_Paper, and FCS_Cloth were 5.9, 6.2, and 5.8%, respectively, which, although slightly less than the PCEs of the OCS versions, are the highest achieved with fully flexible substrates at this moment as far as we know. The PCE reduction ratio (η
FCS
/η
OCS
) was 0.71 for FCS_PET, 0.82 for FCS_Paper, and 0.91 for FCS_Cloth. According to
Figure
3
c, we were able to identify the main factors of the difference in PCE between OCSs and FCSs clearly. Compared with the OCSs, we can be confident that the main factor in reducing the PCE of the FCSs was the decreases in
J
sc
and FF. In general, the reduction of
J
sc
and FF with the efficiency of solar cells is caused by an increase in series resistance and a decrease in shunt resistance, and we can confirm that the same phenomenon occurred in our measurement values. The reasons for the efficiency reduction will be identified in detail through an additional FCS fabricated on PET using optical microscopy, atomic force microscopy (AFM), SEM, a focused ion-beam (FIB) analysis, and nanoindentation in the following sections. To analyze the flexibility of the FCSs, we carried out a bending test on FCS_PET, as can be seen in
Figure
3
d,e. In previous reports on FCSs, not only it was difficult to find detailed reports of flexibility, but also most of the testing was conducted by hand because previously FCSs were fabricated on thin metal substrates such as stainless steel and Mo, which lack flexibility.
(12−18)
Figure S7
shows the setup for the bending testing of the FCSs on PET substrates; the analysis was conducted by varying the bending radius (3–1 cm) and the number of bending cycles (0–500 times).
(27,28)
By using the FCS, we first measured the flexibility while reducing the bending radius. Although the PCE of ∼3% was maintained until the bending radius was greater than 1 cm, at which point cracks appeared on the surface of the CZTSSe solar cell that were visible to the naked eye and the PCE was almost 0%. However, we are confident that future modifications to the adhesive layer in the finished polymer material or packaging for a CZTSSe solar cell will further enhance its flexibility. We fixed the bending radius at 1.3 cm (a stable bending radius) and bent the FCS up to 500 times. As a result, the FCS showed an average PCE of 3.2%,
V
oc
of 393.9 mV,
J
sc
of 17.2 mA/cm
2
, and FF of 47.5%; the FCS_PET cell maintained its performance after 500 bending cycles. Therefore, we confirmed that our FCSs have reliability up to a bending radius of 1.3 cm and 500 bending cycles.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) Photos of the CZTSSe solar cells on various flexible substrates (PET, paper, and cloth). (b) Changes in the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of the OCSs and FCSs and (c)
J
–
V
characteristics of the FCSs on various flexible substrates. Flexibility stress testing according to the (d) bending radius and (e) number of cycles.

div.div: Table 2. Device Characteristics of the Flexible CZTSSe Solar Cells on Various Flexible Substrates

Interestingly, the FCS fabrication method for flexibility evaluation is advantageous in that the transfer method is not merely for producing a single FCS but could also be applied to manufacture a module in which each solar cell is separated and connected in series.
Figure S8
shows a series of manually connected FCSs using silver ribbons on a PET substrate. A schematic diagram is shown in
Figure S8b
, and an
I
–
V
characteristic graph for each sample is shown in
Figure S8c
. When sample 1 with a PCE of 6.18% and sample 2 with a PCE of 6.19% were connected in series, the
V
oc
of the connected FCSs (899.5 mV) was similar to the sum of sample 1 (450.8 mV) and sample 2 (447.9 mV) (
Table S5
). In addition, the current values of the connected FCSs were similar to those of samples 1 and 2.

div.h3: 2.3. Origin of the Degradation of the FCSs
div.div:
We manufactured additional FCSs on PET substrates for the purpose of identifying the cause of random degradation of the FCSs and for reproducibility. The OCSs on SLG used for the fabrication and the completed FCSs on PET substrates were named OCS_PET extra and FCS_PET extra, respectively; the measured results of their properties are recorded in
Table S6
. The extra OCSs showed a higher PCE than the previous OCSs (7.6–8.3%) with a minimum PCE of 7.8% and a maximum PCE of 9.3%. It was confirmed that after transferring to flexible substrates, the PCE was obtained randomly regardless of that of the OCSs, which remained the same as the previous results. In particular, even though the PCE of OCS_PET extra 6 was 9.3%, the PCE after the fabrication of FCS_PET extra 6 was drastically decreased by 4.5% (η
FCS
/η
OCS
= 0.48). On the other hand, the lowest PCE of 7.8% for OCS_PET extra 1 achieved the highest PCE of 7.1% for FCS_PET extra 1 with relatively low degradation of PCE (η
FCS
/η
OCS
= 0.91). To find the origin of the PCE deterioration, FCS_PET extra 1 and 2 were investigated in depth through AFM, SEM, and FIB. The huge difference in the PCE (η
FCS
/η
OCS
= 0.69) between OCS_PET extra 2 and FCS_PET extra 2 was mainly due to the decreases in
J
sc
and FF, as can be seen in
Figure
4
a. We observed the surfaces of FCS_PET extra 1 and 2 with the naked eye at the boundary formed by scribing with a stainless steel razor blade to isolate each solar cell in the OCS fabrication process. Although the surface of the boundary of FCS_PET extra 1 (blue box, a small degradation in PCE) was clean, that of FCS_PET extra 2 (red box, a large degradation in PCE) seems to be damaged to ∼1 mm from the edge, as can be seen in
Figure
4
b. We measured the surface of the boundary in the two solar cells with AFM to observe the surface differences. From the AFM image of FCS_PET extra 1, we were able to observe the usual scribing region with a ∼1 μm depth surface step. In contrast, not only the scribing region on the surface of FCS_PET extra 2 existed, but also an indentation was observed with a ∼3 μm depth surface step in the middle area. To further investigate the differences between these two surfaces, we conducted a FIB analysis on the usual and the unusual interface in the vertical direction of scribing, as can be seen in
Figure
4
c,d. We cut a cross-section of the two boundaries to a length of ∼80 μm with FIB and analyzed the surroundings around the scribing area using SEM, as can be seen in
Figure S9
.
Figure
4
c shows a panoramic view of the scribing region of FCS_PET extra 1 by scaling it to the side of the scribing area and its area. Five additional SEM images were zoomed in from the panoramic images to the left, right, left boundary, right boundary, and the scribing region itself. In the scribing area, it can be seen that only the Mo layer and the MoS
2
/MoSe
2
layer remained as the CZTSSe absorption layer had been removed through the razor scribing, which means that each CZTSSe cell was isolated. The results of the AFM analysis correspond to when the step depth in the scribing area was ∼1 μm. In
Figure
4
c, there was slight physical damage at both edges of the scribed region, albeit the range was narrow. On the other hand, the surface SEM image in
Figure
4
d shows quite widespread damage. To determine the difference, we investigated cross-sectional views of the CZTSSe solar cell through FIB in the same manner as shown in
Figure
4
c. Surprisingly, we found that the Mo layer was broken in the scribing area, as can be seen in the cross-sectional view of
Figure
4
d. Although the physical damage near the scribing region was also found to be the same as shown in
Figure
4
c, we were able to observe that the ZnO-based transparent electrode layer disappeared and the CZTSSe absorber was more severely damaged near the scribing region. In addition, it was confirmed that the ZnO-based transparent electrode layer disappeared ∼25 μm away from the scribing region. In other words, although we conducted the same scribing process to isolate the CZTSSe cells, the Mo layer supporting the absorber layer was broken in the local region. Hence, the HF solution penetrated through the broken Mo layer and chemically damaged the ZnO-based transparent layer and the absorber during the transfer of the FCS, which ultimately led to a decrease in its PCE. If a shunting path was formed between the ZnO and the Mo layer, the overall PCE could have been significantly reduced. Furthermore, we were able to confirm through nanoindentation that the scribing process, which facilitated the isolation with a hard razor blade, could damage the Mo layer locally. We prepared a 1 μm thick Mo layer, a 2 μm thick CZTSSe absorption layer/1 μm thick Mo layer, and the full structure of a CZTSSe solar cell on 2 mm thick SLG, as can be seen in
Figure S10
. The hardness was measured by nanoindentation for each sample. Nanoindentation measurements were carried out in a similar manner as in the cited manuscript, and the hardness was measured after loading to a depth of 600 nm.
(29)
We obtained hardness values of 9.1, 2.3, and 4.1 GPa and Young’s moduli of 162, 53, and 72.8 GPa for the Mo layer, the CZTSSe absorption layer, and the CZTSSe solar cell, respectively, as reported in
Table S7
. Usually, razor blades are made of stainless steel, the hardness and Young’s modulus of which are 9.9 and 223.5 GPa, respectively. Thus, the order of hardness for each material used in the fabrication of the CZTSSe solar cells was determined as follows: razor blade > Mo layer > CZTSSe solar cell > absorber. In other words, the Mo layer could be broken in the region where a strong force was applied locally by the manual scribing with a hard razor blade for the isolation of the CZTSSe solar cell before transferring to the flexible substrate, which means that the HF solution could penetrate and damage the transparent electrode layer and the absorption layer. As a result, it is possible to eliminate the PCE degradation of the FCS and obtain an extremely good high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cell via the adhesive-bonding transfer method if the isolation process is carried out using materials that are weaker than the Mo layer and harder than the CZTSSe solar cell.

div.p:
Figure 4. Extra CZTSSe solar cells: (a) comparison of the
J
–
V
characteristics of the OCSs and the FCSs and (b) a digital camera image of the FCS fabricated on a PET film. There were two boundaries caused by the scribing process on the solar cell identified using AFM measurements: the blue solid line is where there is no damage to the surface, and the red solid line is where the surface has changed. AFM images of the corresponding region and the corresponding height difference are shown. (c, d) SEM surface images of the two boundaries. The panoramic cross-sectional and zoomed-in images were obtained using FIB.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: CZTSSe solar cells using SLG as a substrate require high-temperature heat treatment. In this study, we developed FCSs on PET, paper, and cloth substrates through a polymer-bonding transfer process. As far as we know, this is the first time that diverse flexible substrates have been used in the fabrication of CZTSSe solar cells. The transfer process consists of mechanical etching using a lapping machine and wet etching using HF solution. We used PMMA for protection from the wet solution and TRT for supporting the fabrication of flexible CZTSSe devices. We obtained PCEs of 7.1, 6.7, and 5.9% for the FCSs on the PET, paper, and cloth substrates, respectively. To verify the bending durability of the FCSs obtained by the transfer process, we performed bending up to >1 cm bending radius, repeated this 500 times, and confirmed that there was no reduction in PCE. Finally, we determined the origin of the degradation in PCE of the FCSs through AFM, FIB, and nanoindentation in detail. This study comprises fundamental and essential information about fully nontoxic, wearable ultralight solar cells that will be used in the future and demonstrates the potential for fabricating flexible solar cells using our transfer method.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 4.1. Fabrication of the CZTSSe Solar Cell on SLG
div.div:
A 1 μm thick Mo layer was deposited on 2 mm thick SLG using radio frequency (RF) magnetron sputtering. Zn, Sn, and Cu metal layers were deposited sequentially using 30 W (0.66 W/cm
2
) sputtering power on the Mo/SLG substrates. The purity of the sputtering targets for Mo, Zn, Sn, and Cu was 99.5%, 99.95%, 99.95%, and 99.95%, respectively. The Zn and Cu layers were deposited using direct current (DC) magnetron sputtering, and a Sn layer was deposited using RF magnetron sputtering. During the process, the chamber was filled with Ar gas and the vacuum was maintained at 1.07 Pa. A CZTSSe absorption layer was formed using the metallic precursors and a rapid thermal annealing process. These metallic precursors were slowly heated in a graphite box and maintained at 300 °C for 10 min to form a well-intermixed metal alloy.
(30)
After that, it was cooled at room temperature and quickly heated to 520 °C for 10 min with 50 mg of Se and 2 mg of S powders. To eliminate secondary phases, the CZTSSe thin films were immersed in 0.05 M aqueous KCN solution for 5 min and washed with deionized water. A 60 nm thick CdS buffer layer was deposited at 80 °C using chemical bath deposition. Afterward, 50 nm intrinsic ZnO and 300 nm aluminum-doped ZnO window layers were deposited using RF magnetron sputtering at room temperature and 150 °C, respectively. A 50 nm Ni and 1 μm Al electrodes were deposited through a shadow mask with an electron-beam evaporator, followed by evaporation of a 105 nm thick MgF
2
antireflection coating.

div.h3: 4.2. Adhesive-Bonding Transfer Process to Diverse Substrates
div.div: The back glass of the CZTSSe solar cells completed on 2 mm thick SLG was etched to a depth of 1.5 mm using a lapping machine. To protect the CZTSSe solar cells, a PMMA layer was deposited using a spin coater at 3000 rpm and TRT was attached on the surface of the CZTSSe solar cells, which was subsequently immersed in HF solution for 1 h to completely remove the SLG substrate and then cleaned with deionized water. Afterward, the CZTSSe solar cells were attached to diverse substrates, namely PET, paper, and cloth, using conductive epoxy (Circuitworks, CW2400). Finally, the TRT was removed by heating the sample at 80 °C for 10 min, and PMMA was also removed from the surface of the CZTSSe solar cells using acetone.

SEM (Hitachi S-4700) and TEM-EDX were used for the analysis of the CZTSSe absorption layers and TRT. The crystallinity of the absorption layers was analyzed using XRD (X’pert-APD, Philips) with Cu Kα radiation and Raman scattering measurements (Renishaw, 514 nm line of an Ar-ion laser). The solar cell parameters of the CZTSSe solar cells were measured with a class AAA solar simulator (WXS-155S-L2, WACOM, Japan) under conditions of AM 1.5G, 100 mW/cm
2
, and 25 °C. EQE measurements and the bending test were performed on a QEX7 system (PV Measurements) and a motorized actuator (CONEX-LTA-HS, Newport) at room temperature, respectively.

Biomass energy: the scale of the potential resource
Field Christopher B; Campbell J Elliott; Lobell David B
Trends in ecology & evolution
(

(

ISSN:

.
Increased production of biomass for energy has the potential to offset substantial use of fossil fuels, but it also has the potential to threaten conservation areas, pollute water resources and decrease food security. The net effect of biomass energy agriculture on climate could be either cooling or warming, depending on the crop, the technology for converting biomass into useable energy, and the difference in carbon stocks and reflectance of solar radiation between the biomass crop and the pre-existing vegetation. The area with the greatest potential for yielding biomass energy that reduces net warming and avoids competition with food production is land that was previously used for agriculture or pasture but that has been abandoned and not converted to forest or urban areas. At the global scale, potential above-ground plant growth on these abandoned lands has an energy content representing approximately 5% of world primary energy consumption in 2006. The global potential for biomass energy production is large in absolute terms, but it is not enough to replace more than a few percent of current fossil fuel usage. Increasing biomass energy production beyond this level would probably reduce food security and exacerbate forcing of climate change.

A polymer tandem solar cell with 10.6% power conversion efficiency
You Jingbi; Dou Letian; Yoshimura Ken; Kato Takehito; Ohya Kenichiro; Moriarty Tom; Emery Keith; Chen Chun-Chao; Gao Jing; Li Gang; Yang Yang
Nature communications
(
2013
),
4
(
),
1446
ISSN:
.
An effective way to improve polymer solar cell efficiency is to use a tandem structure, as a broader part of the spectrum of solar radiation is used and the thermalization loss of photon energy is minimized. In the past, the lack of high-performance low-bandgap polymers was the major limiting factor for achieving high-performance tandem solar cell. Here we report the development of a high-performance low bandgap polymer (bandgap <1.4 eV), poly[2,7-(5,5-bis-(3,7-dimethyloctyl)-5H-dithieno[3,2-b:2',3'-d]pyran)-alt-4,7-(5,6-difluoro-2,1,3-benzothia diazole)] with a bandgap of 1.38 eV, high mobility, deep highest occupied molecular orbital. As a result, a single-junction device shows high external quantum efficiency of >60% and spectral response that extends to 900 nm, with a power conversion efficiency of 7.9%. The polymer enables a solution processed tandem solar cell with certified 10.6% power conversion efficiency under standard reporting conditions (25 °C, 1,000 Wm(-2), IEC 60904-3 global), which is the first certified polymer solar cell efficiency over 10%.

Many different photovoltaic technologies are being developed for large-scale solar energy conversion. The wafer-based 1st-generation photovoltaic devices have been followed by thin-film solid semiconductor absorber layers sandwiched between 2 charge-selective contacts and nanostructured (or mesostructured) solar cells that rely on a distributed heterojunction to generate charge and to transport pos. and neg. charges in spatially sepd. phases. Although many materials have been used in nanostructured devices, the goal of attaining high-efficiency thin-film solar cells in such a way has yet to be achieved. Organometal halide perovskites have recently emerged as a promising material for high-efficiency nanostructured devices. Nanostructuring is not necessary to achieve high efficiencies with this material: a simple planar heterojunction solar cell incorporating vapor-deposited perovskite as the absorbing layer can have solar-to-elec. power conversion efficiencies of over 15 per cent (as measured under simulated full sunlight). Perovskite absorbers can function at the highest efficiencies in simplified device architectures, without the need for complex nanostructures.

A band-gap-graded CZTSSe solar cell with 12.3% efficiency
Yang, Kee-Jeong; Son, Dae-Ho; Sung, Shi-Joon; Sim, Jun-Hyoung; Kim, Young-Ill; Park, Si-Nae; Jeon, Dong-Hwan; Kim, JungSik; Hwang, Dae-Kue; Jeon, Chan-Wook; Nam, Dahyun; Cheong, Hyeonsik; Kang, Jin-Kyu; Kim, Dae-Hwan

Although Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) has attracted attention as an alternative to CuInGaSe2 (CIGS) as an absorber material in solar cells, its low efficiency is a serious shortcoming preventing its commercialization. To realize a high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cell, improved grain crystallinity, inhibited secondary-phase formation, controlled defect generation, adequate Na content, and band gap grading are required in the absorber layer. Few studies have focused specifically on band gap grading. In this study, a method of using SeS2, a new potential chalcogenization source material, to control the S and Se contents in a CZTSSe absorber and its effects were investigated. Using an appropriate SeS2/Se wt. ratio, band gap grading was realized within the depletion region. By increasing the value of VOC through band gap grading in the depletion region, a record VOC deficit of 0.576 V was achieved. Furthermore, the possibility of enhancing JSC through the formation of a type-inverted n-type phase at the absorber surface in response to an appropriate alignment of the conduction-band min. energy level and the Fermi energy pinning level is discussed. By introducing the chalcogenization source material SeS2 during the annealing process, CZTSSe solar cells with a max. efficiency of 12.3% were obtained.

A hybrid soln.-particle approach using the earth-abundant Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 system as an example, which enables fabrication of PV devices with >9.6 % power conversion efficiency, is demonstrated. The slurry (or ink) employed for deposition comprises a Cu-Sn chalcogenide (S or S-Se) soln. in hydrazine with the in situ formation of readily dispersible particle-based Zn-chalcogenide precursors, ZnSe(N2H4). TGA of the isolated selenide particle precursor shows decompn. at approx. 200° with a mass loss of about 20%, close to the theor. value expected upon transition to pure ZnSe. Deposition using this hybrid slurry successfully combines the advantages of soln. and suspension deposition routes by use of solns. contg. solid particles, wherein both components (i.e., soln. and particle) contain metal and chalcogen elements that integrate into the final film. Using the hybrid slurry method (a) soly. limitations are resolved, (b) the dissolved components can be engineered as an efficient binding media for the particles,(c) solid particles act as stress-relief and crack-deflection centers allowing the deposition of thicker layers than pure soln. processes, and (d) the intimate contact between the two phases allows rapid reaction and homogeneous phase formation.

In this work we report on the effect of alkali doping via Na and/or K introduction into flexible and light-wt. Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells obtained using a sequential process based on the sputtering of metallic stacks and further reactive annealing. Different thicknesses of Cr diffusion barriers and 50 μm thick ferritic steel substrates were used. We compare different doping methods: Na-doped Mo targets (MoNa), SLG underneath the flexible substrates, NaF and KF pre-absorber synthesis evapn. (PAS) and post-deposition evapn. (PDT). Addnl., we report on the importance of the Cr barrier and back contact modification to improve solar cell performance. A remarkable enhancement in the absorber grain size and surface morphol. occurred esp. when using Na via MoNa and PAS. Nevertheless, preliminary expts. led to better results for MoNa doping due to a higher Na content confirmed by TOF-SIMS. K doping via PAS also showed promising results. An increase in the efficiency of solar cells from 2.2% to 4.3% was possible when using a MoNa layer sandwiched between regular Mo layers. The improvement is mainly related to a higher VOC and FF. After performing a detailed Cr and back contact optimization, a record value of 6.1% for flexible CZTSe solar cells was recently obtained using MoNa and a new surface Ge doping.

Kesterite Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) thin film solar cells are fabricated based on sputtering and post sulfurization process on stainless steel substrates. NaF layers with different thickness are used as external sodium source to address the lack of Na issue in Na-free steel substrates and 10 nm of NaF layer is proved to be the optimal thickness. Sodium incorporation into CZTS induces the metal element redistribution, facilitates CZTS film recrystn. and promotes the phase evolution. Appropriate amt. of sodium is evidenced to yield an enhancement in power conversion efficiency from 3.07% to 4.10% while further increase in sodium tends to deteriorate the device efficiency. Device performance deterioration is correlated to the rather small grain size accompanied with a large amt. of grain boundaries and unfavorable SnS2 secondary phase for CZTS samples without sodium, while pinholes and lower carrier d. in absorber for CZTS samples with over amt. of sodium.

By a simple and economical sol-gel and spin-coating technique, fine quality Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) thin films were formed on flexible molybdenum foils. The CZTS thin films annealed at 500° possessed good compositional, morphol., structural, optical, and elec. properties for solar cells. The best flexible solar cell with a structure of Mo foil/CZTS/CdS/ZnO/AZO/Al exhibited a power conversion efficiency of 2.25%, with short circuit c.d. of 13.52 mA/cm2, open circuit voltage of 370 mV and fill factor of 0.45. Cu2ZnSnS4 layers have been successfully fabricated on flexible polyimide substrates by screen printing. The microparticles of Cu2ZnSnS4, which is the main raw material for prepg. screen printing paste, were prepd. by wet ball milling and sintering methods. X-ray diffraction characterization results show the screen printed Cu2ZnSnS4 layers were well indexed to single phase Cu2ZnSnS4. Scanning electronic microscopy images show the diams. and lengths of the as-prepd. Cu2ZnSnS4 microparticles are about 30-50 and 150-200 nm, resp. The bandgap, sheet resistance, carrier concn., and Hall mobility of the screen printed Cu2ZnSnS4 layers were about 1.49 eV, 2.42 × 103 Ω, 3.81 × 1018 cm-3, and 12.61 cm2 V-1 s-s at 25 °C, resp. To evaluate the photoresponse of the screen printed Cu2ZnSnS4 layers, complete photovoltaic cells with the structure of polyimide/Mo/Cu2ZnSnS4/CdS/ZnO:Al/Al-grid were further fabricated. The short-circuit c.d., open-circuit voltage, fill factor, and efficiency of a typical photovoltaic cell with an active area of 0.15 cm2 were 4.76 mA/cm2, 386 mV, 0.27, and 0.49%, resp.

Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) thin film solar cells were fabricated on 100 μm thick flexible glass (FG) substrates coated with Molybdenum (Mo) anodes. The CZTS thin films were deposited by using magnetron sputtering followed by annealing in sulfur vapor. The fabricated cell structure was FG/Mo/CZTS/CdS/ZnO/ITO/Ag, where cadmium sulfide (CdS), zinc oxide (ZnO), tin-doped indium oxide (ITO) and silver (Ag) were used as an n-type window layer, resistive layer, transparent conductor and finger electrode, resp. The best conversion efficiency achieved of the flexible CZTS solar cell was 3.08%, with an active area of 0.45 cm2. The conversion efficiency was reduced by 20% when the cell was bent to a 50 mm radius.

Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)S4 (CZTSSe) thin films have attracted attention as low-cost absorber materials for solar cells; however, further studies are required to develop flexible solar cells from this material and to achieve a high power conversion efficiency. Toward this objective, this work investigated eight types of precursors applied on flexible Mo foil substrates, some of which also contained a layer of NaF. Secondary phases, defects, and defect clusters were different in the various samples, and the surface elec. characteristics of the CZTSSe absorber layer varied accordingly. In contrast to those in the CIGS-based cells, defects and defect clusters generated in the CZTSSe absorber layer caused an upward band bending-like band structure to form at the grain boundaries (GBs), thereby forming an intra-grain (IG) current path. By improving carrier sepn., a flexible CZTSSe thin-film solar cell was developed on a Mo foil substrate with a power conversion efficiency of 7.04%. Thus, the efficiency of CZTSSe thin-film solar cells could be increased through carrier sepn. measures that enabled the collection of holes toward the GBs and of electrons toward IGs.

Sulfide kesterite Cu2ZnSnS4 provides an attractive low-cost, environmentally benign and stable photovoltaic material, yet the record power conversion efficiency for such solar cells has been stagnant at around 9% for years. Severe non-radiative recombination within the heterojunction region is a major cause limiting voltage output and overall performance. Here we report a certified 11% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 solar cell with a high 730 mV open-circuit voltage using heat treatment to reduce heterojunction recombination. This heat treatment facilitates elemental inter-diffusion, directly inducing Cd atoms to occupy Zn or Cu lattice sites, and promotes Na accumulation accompanied by local Cu deficiency within the heterojunction region. Consequently, new phases are formed near the hetero-interface and more favorable conduction band alignment is obtained, contributing to reduced non-radiative recombination. Using this approach, we also demonstrate a certified centimetre-scale (1.11 cm2) 10% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 photovoltaic device; the first kesterite cell (including selenium-contg.) of std. centimetre-size to exceed 10%.

We investigated limitation factors of high efficiency Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells, where the CZTSSe absorbers were made by using sulfo-selenization process. CZTSSe absorbers with two S/(S+Se) ratios, ∼ 0.12 (Se-rich) and ∼ 0.22 (S-increased), were prepd. by varying the sulfo-selenization temp. The Se-rich CZTSSe solar cells were found to have larger conduction band offset (CBO) between the absorber and the buffer, which was reflected in the kinked J-V curves at low temps. Considering that the larger CBO prevents electron transport from absorber to buffer and resultantly reduces short circuit current and fill factor, it could be possible limitation factor of the high efficiency solar cell. Contrary to Se-rich solar cells, S-increased solar cells showed reduced CBO and no kinked J-V curve. However, deep defects were found to be generated, which induced defect centers of charge recombination both at interface and in bulk of the absorber. The larger CBO in Se-rich CZTSSe solar cell and deep defects in S-increased CZTSSe solar cell are obsd. even in ∼ 12% efficiency solar cells. Thus, we believe that these possible limitation factors should be resolved to achieve high efficiency kesterite CZTSSe solar cell above 12%.

A review. Wafer bonding with intermediate polymer adhesives is an important fabrication technique for advanced microelectronic and microelectromech. systems, such as 3D integrated circuits, advanced packaging, and microfluidics. In adhesive wafer bonding, the polymer adhesive bears the forces involved to hold the surfaces together. The main advantages of adhesive wafer bonding include the insensitivity to surface topog., the low bonding temps., the compatibility with std. integrated circuit wafer processing, and the ability to join different types of wafers. Compared to alternative wafer bonding techniques, adhesive wafer bonding is simple, robust, and low cost. This article reviews the state-of-the-art polymer adhesive wafer bonding technologies, materials, and applications.

Chirila, Adrian; Buecheler, Stephan; Pianezzi, Fabian; Bloesch, Patrick; Gretener, Christina; Uhl, Alexander R.; Fella, Carolin; Kranz, Lukas; Perrenoud, Julian; Seyrling, Sieghard; Verma, Rajneesh; Nishiwaki, Shiro; Romanyuk, Yaroslav E.; Bilger, Gerhard; Tiwari, Ayodhya N.

Solar cells based on polycryst. Cu(In,Ga)Se2 absorber layers have yielded the highest conversion efficiency among all thin-film technologies, and the use of flexible polymer films as substrates offers several advantages in lowering manufg. costs. However, given that conversion efficiency is crucial for cost-competitiveness, it is necessary to develop devices on flexible substrates that perform as well as those obtained on rigid substrates. Such comparable performance has not previously been achieved, primarily because polymer films require much lower substrate temps. during absorber deposition, generally resulting in much lower efficiencies. Here we identify a strong compn. gradient in the absorber layer as the main reason for inferior performance and show that, by adjusting it appropriately, very high efficiencies can be obtained. This implies that future manufg. of highly efficient flexible solar cells could lower the cost of solar electricity and thus become a significant branch of the photovoltaic industry.

The highest efficiencies for both rigid and flexible Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells are still far behind the theor. values. This is mainly due to band tailing in absorber and a large recombination near absorber/Mo interface that block the carrier transportation and lead to Voc and FF degrdn., which are mostly noticeable in flexible solar cells. In this paper, CZTSSe thin films were prepd. on flexible Mo substrates by green soln.-based method followed by selenization. By optimizing selenization conditions (selenization time and temp.), dense and well crystd. CZTSSe thin films without micro-cracks were obtained at 550°C for 12 min. The best efficiency of 6.78% can be achieved with Voc and FF enhanced to 390.43 mV and 57.71%. The dramatic redns. in ideal factor A, series resistance RS, the mismatch Δ(Eg-PL) and potential fluctuation γ indicate that band tailing and recombination are significantly reduced. The performance degrdn. with bending radius and cycles is studied for the first time among CZTSSe solar cells. Results indicate long-term stability at repeatable release-stretch cycles. The flexible CZTSSe solar cells with high stretch ability shed light on the development of flexible solar cells.

Blistering in Cu2ZnSnS4 thin films: correlation with residual stresses
Malerba, C.; Valentini, M.; Azanza Ricardo, C. L.; Rinaldi, A.; Cappelletto, E.; Scardi, P.; Mittiga, A.

An investigation is presented on the blistering of Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) thin films grown by sulfurization of co-sputtered quaternary precursors. SEM cross-sectional images of post-annealed samples show film delamination occurring at the CZTS/substrate interface, with formation of blisters whose diam. typically ranges between 10 and 60 μm and height between 3 and 10 μm. Two main competing mechanisms suggested by the literature on different materials have been considered to explain blistering in CZTS, resp. based on the relief of compressive stress or on the formation of over-pressurized trapped-gas bubbles. Intrinsic residual stress in as-sputtered precursor layers was measured by substrate-curvature and by X-ray diffraction techniques. Results show that by increasing the sputtering pressure both compressive stress in precursors and blistering extent in the corresponding CZTS film decrease. A mechanism based on stress-driven viscoplastic deformation is proposed to explain blistering in CZTS films, while trapped-Ar pressure seems to play just a secondary role.

Chen, Wei-Chao; Tunuguntla, Venkatesh; Li, Hsien-Wen; Chen, Cheng-Ying; Li, Shao-Sian; Hwang, Jih-Shang; Lee, Chin-Hao; Chen, Li-Chyong; Chen, Kuei-Hsien

In this study, we proposed a 4-step selenization process for the RF-sputtered Cu-Zn/Sn metallic stack to prep. Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) absorber. We applied a pre-heating treatment for the metal stack under vacuum prior to the selenization, which plays an important role to form a well inter mixed alloy with relatively smooth thin film morphol. The nucleation temps. were controlled precisely from 150 °C to 500 °C during 4-step selenization to avoid the formation of secondary phases and to improve the crystal quality of CZTSe with a greater homogeneity in the compn. The formation of various phases during each step in 4-step selenization process were studied by X-ray Diffraction, Raman anal. and we proposed a possible reaction mechanism of the CZTSe formation with binary and ternary compds. as intermediates. We also performed optical anal., including Uv-Visible absorption and low temp. photoluminescence, and scanning transmission electron microscope anal. for the CZTSe samples. Finally, an efficiency of 5.8% CZTSe solar cell is fabricated with an open circuit voltage of 370 mV, short circuit current of 31.99 mA/cm2, and a fill factor of 48.3%.

To provide a truly widespread primary energy source, solar energy must be captured, converted, and stored in a cost-effective fashion. New developments in nanotechnol., biotechnol., and the materials and phys. sciences may enable step-change approaches to cost-effective, globally scalable systems for solar energy use.

Biomass energy: the scale of the potential resource
Field Christopher B; Campbell J Elliott; Lobell David B
Trends in ecology & evolution
(
2008
),
23
(
2
),
65-72
ISSN:
0169-5347
.
Increased production of biomass for energy has the potential to offset substantial use of fossil fuels, but it also has the potential to threaten conservation areas, pollute water resources and decrease food security. The net effect of biomass energy agriculture on climate could be either cooling or warming, depending on the crop, the technology for converting biomass into useable energy, and the difference in carbon stocks and reflectance of solar radiation between the biomass crop and the pre-existing vegetation. The area with the greatest potential for yielding biomass energy that reduces net warming and avoids competition with food production is land that was previously used for agriculture or pasture but that has been abandoned and not converted to forest or urban areas. At the global scale, potential above-ground plant growth on these abandoned lands has an energy content representing approximately 5% of world primary energy consumption in 2006. The global potential for biomass energy production is large in absolute terms, but it is not enough to replace more than a few percent of current fossil fuel usage. Increasing biomass energy production beyond this level would probably reduce food security and exacerbate forcing of climate change.

A polymer tandem solar cell with 10.6% power conversion efficiency
You Jingbi; Dou Letian; Yoshimura Ken; Kato Takehito; Ohya Kenichiro; Moriarty Tom; Emery Keith; Chen Chun-Chao; Gao Jing; Li Gang; Yang Yang
Nature communications
(
2013
),
4
(
),
1446
ISSN:
.
An effective way to improve polymer solar cell efficiency is to use a tandem structure, as a broader part of the spectrum of solar radiation is used and the thermalization loss of photon energy is minimized. In the past, the lack of high-performance low-bandgap polymers was the major limiting factor for achieving high-performance tandem solar cell. Here we report the development of a high-performance low bandgap polymer (bandgap <1.4 eV), poly[2,7-(5,5-bis-(3,7-dimethyloctyl)-5H-dithieno[3,2-b:2',3'-d]pyran)-alt-4,7-(5,6-difluoro-2,1,3-benzothia diazole)] with a bandgap of 1.38 eV, high mobility, deep highest occupied molecular orbital. As a result, a single-junction device shows high external quantum efficiency of >60% and spectral response that extends to 900 nm, with a power conversion efficiency of 7.9%. The polymer enables a solution processed tandem solar cell with certified 10.6% power conversion efficiency under standard reporting conditions (25 °C, 1,000 Wm(-2), IEC 60904-3 global), which is the first certified polymer solar cell efficiency over 10%.

Liu, Mingzhen; Johnston, Michael B.; Snaith, Henry J.

Many different photovoltaic technologies are being developed for large-scale solar energy conversion. The wafer-based 1st-generation photovoltaic devices have been followed by thin-film solid semiconductor absorber layers sandwiched between 2 charge-selective contacts and nanostructured (or mesostructured) solar cells that rely on a distributed heterojunction to generate charge and to transport pos. and neg. charges in spatially sepd. phases. Although many materials have been used in nanostructured devices, the goal of attaining high-efficiency thin-film solar cells in such a way has yet to be achieved. Organometal halide perovskites have recently emerged as a promising material for high-efficiency nanostructured devices. Nanostructuring is not necessary to achieve high efficiencies with this material: a simple planar heterojunction solar cell incorporating vapor-deposited perovskite as the absorbing layer can have solar-to-elec. power conversion efficiencies of over 15 per cent (as measured under simulated full sunlight). Perovskite absorbers can function at the highest efficiencies in simplified device architectures, without the need for complex nanostructures.

Although Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) has attracted attention as an alternative to CuInGaSe2 (CIGS) as an absorber material in solar cells, its low efficiency is a serious shortcoming preventing its commercialization. To realize a high-efficiency CZTSSe solar cell, improved grain crystallinity, inhibited secondary-phase formation, controlled defect generation, adequate Na content, and band gap grading are required in the absorber layer. Few studies have focused specifically on band gap grading. In this study, a method of using SeS2, a new potential chalcogenization source material, to control the S and Se contents in a CZTSSe absorber and its effects were investigated. Using an appropriate SeS2/Se wt. ratio, band gap grading was realized within the depletion region. By increasing the value of VOC through band gap grading in the depletion region, a record VOC deficit of 0.576 V was achieved. Furthermore, the possibility of enhancing JSC through the formation of a type-inverted n-type phase at the absorber surface in response to an appropriate alignment of the conduction-band min. energy level and the Fermi energy pinning level is discussed. By introducing the chalcogenization source material SeS2 during the annealing process, CZTSSe solar cells with a max. efficiency of 12.3% were obtained.

A hybrid soln.-particle approach using the earth-abundant Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 system as an example, which enables fabrication of PV devices with >9.6 % power conversion efficiency, is demonstrated. The slurry (or ink) employed for deposition comprises a Cu-Sn chalcogenide (S or S-Se) soln. in hydrazine with the in situ formation of readily dispersible particle-based Zn-chalcogenide precursors, ZnSe(N2H4). TGA of the isolated selenide particle precursor shows decompn. at approx. 200° with a mass loss of about 20%, close to the theor. value expected upon transition to pure ZnSe. Deposition using this hybrid slurry successfully combines the advantages of soln. and suspension deposition routes by use of solns. contg. solid particles, wherein both components (i.e., soln. and particle) contain metal and chalcogen elements that integrate into the final film. Using the hybrid slurry method (a) soly. limitations are resolved, (b) the dissolved components can be engineered as an efficient binding media for the particles,(c) solid particles act as stress-relief and crack-deflection centers allowing the deposition of thicker layers than pure soln. processes, and (d) the intimate contact between the two phases allows rapid reaction and homogeneous phase formation.

In this work we report on the effect of alkali doping via Na and/or K introduction into flexible and light-wt. Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) solar cells obtained using a sequential process based on the sputtering of metallic stacks and further reactive annealing. Different thicknesses of Cr diffusion barriers and 50 μm thick ferritic steel substrates were used. We compare different doping methods: Na-doped Mo targets (MoNa), SLG underneath the flexible substrates, NaF and KF pre-absorber synthesis evapn. (PAS) and post-deposition evapn. (PDT). Addnl., we report on the importance of the Cr barrier and back contact modification to improve solar cell performance. A remarkable enhancement in the absorber grain size and surface morphol. occurred esp. when using Na via MoNa and PAS. Nevertheless, preliminary expts. led to better results for MoNa doping due to a higher Na content confirmed by TOF-SIMS. K doping via PAS also showed promising results. An increase in the efficiency of solar cells from 2.2% to 4.3% was possible when using a MoNa layer sandwiched between regular Mo layers. The improvement is mainly related to a higher VOC and FF. After performing a detailed Cr and back contact optimization, a record value of 6.1% for flexible CZTSe solar cells was recently obtained using MoNa and a new surface Ge doping.

Kesterite Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) thin film solar cells are fabricated based on sputtering and post sulfurization process on stainless steel substrates. NaF layers with different thickness are used as external sodium source to address the lack of Na issue in Na-free steel substrates and 10 nm of NaF layer is proved to be the optimal thickness. Sodium incorporation into CZTS induces the metal element redistribution, facilitates CZTS film recrystn. and promotes the phase evolution. Appropriate amt. of sodium is evidenced to yield an enhancement in power conversion efficiency from 3.07% to 4.10% while further increase in sodium tends to deteriorate the device efficiency. Device performance deterioration is correlated to the rather small grain size accompanied with a large amt. of grain boundaries and unfavorable SnS2 secondary phase for CZTS samples without sodium, while pinholes and lower carrier d. in absorber for CZTS samples with over amt. of sodium.

Cu2ZnSnS4 layers have been successfully fabricated on flexible polyimide substrates by screen printing. The microparticles of Cu2ZnSnS4, which is the main raw material for prepg. screen printing paste, were prepd. by wet ball milling and sintering methods. X-ray diffraction characterization results show the screen printed Cu2ZnSnS4 layers were well indexed to single phase Cu2ZnSnS4. Scanning electronic microscopy images show the diams. and lengths of the as-prepd. Cu2ZnSnS4 microparticles are about 30-50 and 150-200 nm, resp. The bandgap, sheet resistance, carrier concn., and Hall mobility of the screen printed Cu2ZnSnS4 layers were about 1.49 eV, 2.42 × 103 Ω, 3.81 × 1018 cm-3, and 12.61 cm2 V-1 s-s at 25 °C, resp. To evaluate the photoresponse of the screen printed Cu2ZnSnS4 layers, complete photovoltaic cells with the structure of polyimide/Mo/Cu2ZnSnS4/CdS/ZnO:Al/Al-grid were further fabricated. The short-circuit c.d., open-circuit voltage, fill factor, and efficiency of a typical photovoltaic cell with an active area of 0.15 cm2 were 4.76 mA/cm2, 386 mV, 0.27, and 0.49%, resp.

Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) thin film solar cells were fabricated on 100 μm thick flexible glass (FG) substrates coated with Molybdenum (Mo) anodes. The CZTS thin films were deposited by using magnetron sputtering followed by annealing in sulfur vapor. The fabricated cell structure was FG/Mo/CZTS/CdS/ZnO/ITO/Ag, where cadmium sulfide (CdS), zinc oxide (ZnO), tin-doped indium oxide (ITO) and silver (Ag) were used as an n-type window layer, resistive layer, transparent conductor and finger electrode, resp. The best conversion efficiency achieved of the flexible CZTS solar cell was 3.08%, with an active area of 0.45 cm2. The conversion efficiency was reduced by 20% when the cell was bent to a 50 mm radius.

Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)S4 (CZTSSe) thin films have attracted attention as low-cost absorber materials for solar cells; however, further studies are required to develop flexible solar cells from this material and to achieve a high power conversion efficiency. Toward this objective, this work investigated eight types of precursors applied on flexible Mo foil substrates, some of which also contained a layer of NaF. Secondary phases, defects, and defect clusters were different in the various samples, and the surface elec. characteristics of the CZTSSe absorber layer varied accordingly. In contrast to those in the CIGS-based cells, defects and defect clusters generated in the CZTSSe absorber layer caused an upward band bending-like band structure to form at the grain boundaries (GBs), thereby forming an intra-grain (IG) current path. By improving carrier sepn., a flexible CZTSSe thin-film solar cell was developed on a Mo foil substrate with a power conversion efficiency of 7.04%. Thus, the efficiency of CZTSSe thin-film solar cells could be increased through carrier sepn. measures that enabled the collection of holes toward the GBs and of electrons toward IGs.

Sulfide kesterite Cu2ZnSnS4 provides an attractive low-cost, environmentally benign and stable photovoltaic material, yet the record power conversion efficiency for such solar cells has been stagnant at around 9% for years. Severe non-radiative recombination within the heterojunction region is a major cause limiting voltage output and overall performance. Here we report a certified 11% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 solar cell with a high 730 mV open-circuit voltage using heat treatment to reduce heterojunction recombination. This heat treatment facilitates elemental inter-diffusion, directly inducing Cd atoms to occupy Zn or Cu lattice sites, and promotes Na accumulation accompanied by local Cu deficiency within the heterojunction region. Consequently, new phases are formed near the hetero-interface and more favorable conduction band alignment is obtained, contributing to reduced non-radiative recombination. Using this approach, we also demonstrate a certified centimetre-scale (1.11 cm2) 10% efficiency Cu2ZnSnS4 photovoltaic device; the first kesterite cell (including selenium-contg.) of std. centimetre-size to exceed 10%.

We investigated limitation factors of high efficiency Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells, where the CZTSSe absorbers were made by using sulfo-selenization process. CZTSSe absorbers with two S/(S+Se) ratios, ∼ 0.12 (Se-rich) and ∼ 0.22 (S-increased), were prepd. by varying the sulfo-selenization temp. The Se-rich CZTSSe solar cells were found to have larger conduction band offset (CBO) between the absorber and the buffer, which was reflected in the kinked J-V curves at low temps. Considering that the larger CBO prevents electron transport from absorber to buffer and resultantly reduces short circuit current and fill factor, it could be possible limitation factor of the high efficiency solar cell. Contrary to Se-rich solar cells, S-increased solar cells showed reduced CBO and no kinked J-V curve. However, deep defects were found to be generated, which induced defect centers of charge recombination both at interface and in bulk of the absorber. The larger CBO in Se-rich CZTSSe solar cell and deep defects in S-increased CZTSSe solar cell are obsd. even in ∼ 12% efficiency solar cells. Thus, we believe that these possible limitation factors should be resolved to achieve high efficiency kesterite CZTSSe solar cell above 12%.

A review. Wafer bonding with intermediate polymer adhesives is an important fabrication technique for advanced microelectronic and microelectromech. systems, such as 3D integrated circuits, advanced packaging, and microfluidics. In adhesive wafer bonding, the polymer adhesive bears the forces involved to hold the surfaces together. The main advantages of adhesive wafer bonding include the insensitivity to surface topog., the low bonding temps., the compatibility with std. integrated circuit wafer processing, and the ability to join different types of wafers. Compared to alternative wafer bonding techniques, adhesive wafer bonding is simple, robust, and low cost. This article reviews the state-of-the-art polymer adhesive wafer bonding technologies, materials, and applications.

Highly efficient Cu(In,Ga)Se2 solar cells grown on flexible polymer films

Solar cells based on polycryst. Cu(In,Ga)Se2 absorber layers have yielded the highest conversion efficiency among all thin-film technologies, and the use of flexible polymer films as substrates offers several advantages in lowering manufg. costs. However, given that conversion efficiency is crucial for cost-competitiveness, it is necessary to develop devices on flexible substrates that perform as well as those obtained on rigid substrates. Such comparable performance has not previously been achieved, primarily because polymer films require much lower substrate temps. during absorber deposition, generally resulting in much lower efficiencies. Here we identify a strong compn. gradient in the absorber layer as the main reason for inferior performance and show that, by adjusting it appropriately, very high efficiencies can be obtained. This implies that future manufg. of highly efficient flexible solar cells could lower the cost of solar electricity and thus become a significant branch of the photovoltaic industry.

The highest efficiencies for both rigid and flexible Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) solar cells are still far behind the theor. values. This is mainly due to band tailing in absorber and a large recombination near absorber/Mo interface that block the carrier transportation and lead to Voc and FF degrdn., which are mostly noticeable in flexible solar cells. In this paper, CZTSSe thin films were prepd. on flexible Mo substrates by green soln.-based method followed by selenization. By optimizing selenization conditions (selenization time and temp.), dense and well crystd. CZTSSe thin films without micro-cracks were obtained at 550°C for 12 min. The best efficiency of 6.78% can be achieved with Voc and FF enhanced to 390.43 mV and 57.71%. The dramatic redns. in ideal factor A, series resistance RS, the mismatch Δ(Eg-PL) and potential fluctuation γ indicate that band tailing and recombination are significantly reduced. The performance degrdn. with bending radius and cycles is studied for the first time among CZTSSe solar cells. Results indicate long-term stability at repeatable release-stretch cycles. The flexible CZTSSe solar cells with high stretch ability shed light on the development of flexible solar cells.

Blistering in Cu2ZnSnS4 thin films: correlation with residual stresses
Malerba, C.; Valentini, M.; Azanza Ricardo, C. L.; Rinaldi, A.; Cappelletto, E.; Scardi, P.; Mittiga, A.

An investigation is presented on the blistering of Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) thin films grown by sulfurization of co-sputtered quaternary precursors. SEM cross-sectional images of post-annealed samples show film delamination occurring at the CZTS/substrate interface, with formation of blisters whose diam. typically ranges between 10 and 60 μm and height between 3 and 10 μm. Two main competing mechanisms suggested by the literature on different materials have been considered to explain blistering in CZTS, resp. based on the relief of compressive stress or on the formation of over-pressurized trapped-gas bubbles. Intrinsic residual stress in as-sputtered precursor layers was measured by substrate-curvature and by X-ray diffraction techniques. Results show that by increasing the sputtering pressure both compressive stress in precursors and blistering extent in the corresponding CZTS film decrease. A mechanism based on stress-driven viscoplastic deformation is proposed to explain blistering in CZTS films, while trapped-Ar pressure seems to play just a secondary role.

Fabrication of Cu2ZnSnSe4 solar cells through multi-step selenization of layered metallic precursor film
Chen, Wei-Chao; Tunuguntla, Venkatesh; Li, Hsien-Wen; Chen, Cheng-Ying; Li, Shao-Sian; Hwang, Jih-Shang; Lee, Chin-Hao; Chen, Li-Chyong; Chen, Kuei-Hsien

In this study, we proposed a 4-step selenization process for the RF-sputtered Cu-Zn/Sn metallic stack to prep. Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) absorber. We applied a pre-heating treatment for the metal stack under vacuum prior to the selenization, which plays an important role to form a well inter mixed alloy with relatively smooth thin film morphol. The nucleation temps. were controlled precisely from 150 °C to 500 °C during 4-step selenization to avoid the formation of secondary phases and to improve the crystal quality of CZTSe with a greater homogeneity in the compn. The formation of various phases during each step in 4-step selenization process were studied by X-ray Diffraction, Raman anal. and we proposed a possible reaction mechanism of the CZTSe formation with binary and ternary compds. as intermediates. We also performed optical anal., including Uv-Visible absorption and low temp. photoluminescence, and scanning transmission electron microscope anal. for the CZTSe samples. Finally, an efficiency of 5.8% CZTSe solar cell is fabricated with an open circuit voltage of 370 mV, short circuit current of 31.99 mA/cm2, and a fill factor of 48.3%.
